# How do mileage and year affect price?

--
```{r mileage_year, fig.height=5, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(firasans)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(extrafont)
library(tidyverse)
library(vtable)
library(patchwork)

luxury_brands <- c("Audi", "BMW", "Cadillac", "Ferrari", "Jaguar", "Lamborghini", "Land Rover", "Lexus",
                   "Maserati", "Mercedes-Benz", "Porsche", "Rolls-Royce", "Tesla", "Volvo")

cars <- cars %>% filter(type != "new" & mileage >= 10000 & mileage <= 150000 & price < 100000 & year >= 1970) %>%
  mutate(luxury = ifelse(make %in% luxury_brands, 1, 0),
         price = price/1000,
         mileage = mileage/1000,
         year = year - 1970)

g1 <- ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = mileage, y = price)) +
  geom_point(color = "#F89441", fill = "white", pch=21, size = 2) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Mileage") + ylab("Price") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g2 <- ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = year, y = price)) +
  geom_point(color = "#E16462", fill = "white", pch=21, size = 2) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Year") + ylab("Price") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g1 + g2
```

# Let's run a model

--
.small[
```{r}
lm1 <- lm(price ~ year + mileage + rating, data = cars)

summary(lm1)
```
]

- Why do you think these **.darkorange[partial correlations]** are both negative for `year` and `mileage`?

---
# Multicollinearity in Regressors

- If two covariates are **.darkorange[highly correlated]**, it is difficult to separate the contribution of each!

  - E.g. They move together

--

- **.darkorange[Be careful]** with interpretations

  - The same with extrapolation zones!

---
# Models with interactions

- You include the interaction between two (or more) covariates:

$$\widehat{Price} = \beta_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 Rating + \hat{\beta}_2 Miles + \hat{\beta}_3 Luxury + \hat{\beta}_4 Year + \hat{\beta}_5 Luxury \times Year$$
--

  - $\hat{\beta}_3$ and $\hat{\beta}_4$ are considered the **.darkorange[main effects]** (no interaction)

--

- The coefficient you are interested in is $\hat{\beta}_5$:

  - Difference in the **.darkorange[price change]** for one additional year between **.darkorange[luxury vs non-luxury cars]**, holding other variables constant.
  
---

Let's look at what's left

---
# Residuals in an OLS regression

- **.darkorange[Residuals]** are a fundamental part of OLS regression: They represent what is not explained by the covariates.

--

- When making *probabilistic inference*, we assume (among other things):

  - The distribution of the error term is **.darkorange[normal]**
  - The error terms are **.darkorange[iid]** (independent and identically distributed).
  
--

.box-7Trans[$$\varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma)$$]

---
# Let's look at the residuals

```{r, eval = FALSE}
cars <- cars %>% mutate(price_hat = predict(lm(price ~ rating + mileage + year, data = .)), 
                        residual = price - price_hat)

ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = residual)) + geom_histogram()
```
```{r resid_hist, fig.height=4.5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
cars <- cars %>% mutate(price_hat = predict(lm(price ~ rating + mileage + year, data = .)), 
                        residual = price - price_hat)

ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = residual)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "#BF3984", fill = "white", lwd = 1.5) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Residuals") + ylab("Count") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Let's look at the variance!

```{r, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = price_hat, y = residual)) + geom_point()
```
```{r resid_scatter, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = price_hat, y = residual)) +
  geom_point(color = "#BF3984", fill = "white", pch=21, size = 3) + 
      geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 0), color = "dark grey", lwd = 1) +
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Fitted values") + ylab("Residuals") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Can we fix that?

```{r, eval = FALSE}
cars <- cars %>% mutate(price_hat = predict(lm(log(price) ~ rating + mileage + year, data = .)), #<<
                        residual = log(price) - price_hat) #<<

ggplot(data = cars, aes(x = price_hat, y = residual)) + geom_point()
```
